Award.AwardTitle: Bio-Inspired Design, Fabrication and Testing of Bipolar Plates for PEM Fuel Cells

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this award is to improve the power density of Proton Exchange Membrane fuel cells using a bio-inspired design. Graphite composite bipolar plates will be designed with complex flow paths modeled after leaf structures and fabricated using selective laser sintering, an additive manufacturing process that enables manufacture of the complex designs. Optimization of the design will be based on mathematical flow models taking into account governing mass, momentum, species and charge conservation. Experiments will be conducted to verify accuracy of finite element analyses of power density versus pressure distribution. Power density comparisons will be made with bipolar plates of conventional design.

If successful, this research is expected to yield a new approach to the design and manufacture of Proton Exchange Membrane fuel cells that will have more efficient fuel transport and water removal. This could lead to more widespread adoption of fuel cell technologies for energy conversion across a variety of applications.

Institution.Name: Missouri University of Science and Technology

Performance_Institution.Name: Missouri University of Science and Technology

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of the project were to generate a better understanding about the working of the flow field of a bipolar plate in a polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) fuel cell and to generate useful knowledge from this understanding to design and manufacture of PEM fuel cells.  The specific objectives were to understand how the flow field of a bipolar plate distributes reactants and removes the produced water in PEM fuel cells and to maximize the power density of PEM fuel cells.

 

The project has generated fundamental knowledge on the functions and working of the flow field of a bipolar plate in a PEM fuel cell. We have developed a network based optimization model that can be applied to optimize different flow field configurations for a bipolar plate. The superior performance of the bio-inspired flow field, in comparison to conventional flow fields, has been demonstrated both numerically and experimentally. The project team included 2 professors, 4 graduate students and 7 undergraduate students, providing them with valuable experiences in the investigation of design strategy, fluid mechanics, heat transfer and electrochemistry of PEM fuel cell as well as the fabrication and testing of bipolar plates and fuel cells.

 

The project contributes to research and education resources through journal publications and conference presentations. We have already published 6 papers in scientific journals and 6 papers in proceedings of professional conferences. The main research activities and findings of the project are summarized below:

  • CFD simulation has been conducted to understand the characteristics of flow fields in PEM fuel cell bipolar plates and to compare the performance of a fuel cell with bio-inspired vs. conventional flow fields (single serpentine, parallel in series, etc.). The simulation results demonstrated the superior performance of a bio-inspired flow field, with significant increase in peak power density compared to conventional flow fields. The simulation results also showed that increasing the ratio of interdigitated area to active area on the bipolar plate, within a reasonable range, improves the performance of a PEM fuel cell, because the under-rib flows assists in the supply of reactants to catalyst layers and removal of the water product.
  • A network based optimization model that can be applied to optimize different flow fields for bipolar plates used in PEM fuel cells has been developed. The Matlab code written based on this optimization model has been used to optimize several flow field configurations including pin-type, parallel, parallel-in-series, serpentine, and bio-inspired designs. The numerical simulations of flow distributions in bipolar plates have validated that the optimization model works for all the flow field configurations investigated.
  • CFD simulation has been conducted to investigate the performance of five-unit fuel cell stacks with single serpentine and bio-inspired flow fields. The results demonstrated that a fuel cell stack with bio-inspired flow fields has less fluctuations among different cells and higher performance overall compared to one with single serpentine flow fields
  • Physical prototypes of bipolar plates have been fabricated by use of selective laser sintering, carbonization and infiltration processes. These bipolar plates were used in experimental testing to investigate the performance of PEM fuel cells with bio-inspired bipolar plates compared to conventional bipolar plates. The experimental results with the fabricated bipolar plates confirmed the conclusion from the simulation results that the bio-inspired flow field has superior performance compared to conventional flow fields. The experimental results also demonstrated that the interdigitated nature of bio-inspired flow field enhances the water removal ability with u...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The major goals of the project were to generate a better understanding about the working of the flow field of a bipolar plate in a polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) fuel cell and to generate useful knowledge from this understanding to design and manufacture of PEM fuel cells. The specific objectives were to understand how the flow field of a bipolar plate distributes reactants and removes the produced water in PEM fuel cells and to maximize the power density of PEM fuel cells. The project has generated fundamental knowledge on the functions and working of the flow field of a bipolar plate in a PEM fuel cell. We have developed a network based optimization model that can be applied to optimize different flow field configurations for a bipolar plate. The superior performance of the bio-inspired flow field, in comparison to conventional flow fields, has been demonstrated both numerically and experimentally. The project team included 2 professors, 4 graduate students and 7 undergraduate students, providing them with valuable experiences in the investigation of design strategy, fluid mechanics, heat transfer and electrochemistry of PEM fuel cell as well as the fabrication and testing of bipolar plates and fuel cells. The project contributes to research and education resources through journal publications and conference presentations. We have already published 6 papers in scientific journals and 6 papers in proceedings of professional conferences. The main research activities and findings of the project are summarized below: CFD simulation has been conducted to understand the characteristics of flow fields in PEM fuel cell bipolar plates and to compare the performance of a fuel cell with bio-inspired vs. conventional flow fields (single serpentine, parallel in series, etc.). The simulation results demonstrated the superior performance of a bio-inspired flow field, with significant increase in peak power density compared to conventional flow fields. The simulation results also showed that increasing the ratio of interdigitated area to active area on the bipolar plate, within a reasonable range, improves the performance of a PEM fuel cell, because the under-rib flows assists in the supply of reactants to catalyst layers and removal of the water product. A network based optimization model that can be applied to optimize different flow fields for bipolar plates used in PEM fuel cells has been developed. The Matlab code written based on this optimization model has been used to optimize several flow field configurations including pin-type, parallel, parallel-in-series, serpentine, and bio-inspired designs. The numerical simulations of flow distributions in bipolar plates have validated that the optimization model works for all the flow field configurations investigated. CFD simulation has been conducted to investigate the performance of five-unit fuel cell stacks with single serpentine and bio-inspired flow fields. The results demonstrated that a fuel cell stack with bio-inspired flow fields has less fluctuations among different cells and higher performance overall compared to one with single serpentine flow fields Physical prototypes of bipolar plates have been fabricated by use of selective laser sintering, carbonization and infiltration processes. These bipolar plates were used in experimental testing to investigate the performance of PEM fuel cells with bio-inspired bipolar plates compared to conventional bipolar plates. The experimental results with the fabricated bipolar plates confirmed the conclusion from the simulation results that the bio-inspired flow field has superior performance compared to conventional flow fields. The experimental results also demonstrated that the interdigitated nature of bio-inspired flow field enhances the water removal ability with under-rib flows, especially at a high current density operating condition.
